oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Abstract of ordnance materials expended or consumed by Company K, 5th Regiment, Tennessee Cavalry
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- Army -- Ordnance and ordnance stores
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-page printed and handwritten Federal Form No. 9 (a) reflects the type of ammunition consumed and how and where it was used over a particular time period for Company K, 5th Regiment, Tennessee Cavalry, United States Army. In this case, the ammunition was used in actions and skirmishes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Army -- Ordnance Corps
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ammunition listings for this federal unit reflect weapons commonly used by Civil War cavalry soldiers. James H. Merrill, a Baltimore gunsmith, designed the breechloading Merrill Carbine, an early contract carbine. Samuel Colt of Hartford, Connecticut, produced the most handguns during the Civil War period, including the Colt Army Pistol (1860 "New Model Army"); he produced 150,000 of these six-shot revolvers. His .36 caliber "Navy" model revolver was introduced in 1851.
